The second is the specific explanation of the fragrant seas of the various buddha lands. The double explanation of the two chapters means that the fragrant seas
rely on the sea of buddha lands, the various buddha lands rely on the fragrant seas, and the various buddha lands rely on the various buddha lands.
There are also prose and verse.
The prose is divided into three parts:
First, a general statement of the bases of the various seas; second, a detailed explanation of the various buddha lands and the various buddha lands; third, a brief concluding explanation.
Now, the first.

Although the previous text only mentions the two chapters of the various buddha lands and the various buddha lands, in the explanation of the basis and support, it says they rely on the seas, so it lists the number of seas.
These many fragrant seas are all on the ground of the sea of buddha lands, so it says the bases.
As for like the net of Indra, the overall distribution is like a chariot wheel.

Those that are different are the jeweled nets of Indra's palace, strung with heavenly pearls, with one large pearl in the center, then the next largest pearl strung through it, circling around like this, turning and turning, passing through hundreds of thousands of circles.
If one looks at the four sides and four corners above and below, they all correspond in rows.
Now, although this fragrant ocean is on the ground, its distribution is similar.
There is also the meaning of interpenetration, so it is said to be like this.
Second, All Buddha-sons, this is the middle... and below, it sequentially reveals the various oceans and lands.

The text is divided into three parts. First, it discusses the one ocean in the middle; second, it discusses the ten oceans that turn to the right; third, it clarifies the oceans governed by the ten oceans.

However, each of the ten oceans governs oceans as numerous as the dust particles in an ineffable number of Buddha lands. If they are collectively revealed, there are ten ineffable numbers of Buddha lands.
If they are sequentially discussed, there are only one hundred and eleven oceans, the rest are briefly indicated.
First, the central ocean has two parts:
First, it clarifies that the fragrant ocean produces flowers to support the seed of the realm. Later, there are unspeakable... clarifies the world that is supported.
There are three in the former:
First, the name of the fragrant ocean. Because many flowers emit light, it is also because of the cause of the practice of the bodhisattva's flower.
Second, the name of the flower. It is said that this flower is adorned with fragrant maá¹‡i jewels, and it is also born from the bottom of the maá¹‡i jewel.
In terms of the Dharma, it is because it is accomplished by the perfect illumination of myriad practices.ğŸ”½The ocean is able to have flowers, so it receives the name of flowers;
The flowers rely on the ocean, taking the name of the ocean floor.
Third, the name of the seed. In terms of events, the precious light shines far.

In terms of the Dharma, the seed of the world realm is precisely the contained seed. Each has the meaning of the great wisdom light illuminating the Dharma realm, and the nature virtues mutually adorn each other.
The second, the supported world, has three parts:

First, it generally mentions the large number, next, below The very bottom it specifically discusses the twenty layers of great temples, and finally, below All you children of Buddha it concludes the rest by analogy.
The first passage can be understood.ğŸ”½In the second specific discussion, according to the heading and conclusion, there are ineffable numbers of buddha lands.
In the specific discussion, it only lists nineteen buddha lands as the twenty layers.
The surrounding lands only have two hundred and ten buddha lands, which will be explained below.
The twenty layers are divided into twenty sections.
In the lowest layer, there are seven points in the text: First, it mentions the name.
Second, it discusses the boundary, referring to the boundary where the world is based, like the diamond boundary.

Third, the basis of support. If this name is based on the lotus flower that supports the great trichiliocosm, the old commentary says that above the boundless fragrant ocean there is this lotus flower that supports this single world system, taking this as an analogy for the separate basis of support for the upper layers, thus this explanation is given. How can it be that the lowest one is based on the general lotus flower? Think about it.
Fourth, the shape is like a maá¹‡i jewel. It has eight corners, resembling a square but not a square, resembling a circle but not a circle, thus differing from the eight corners below.
Fifth, the covering above.
Sixth, the retinue.
Seventh, the name of the Buddha of the main world is the Lamp of the Pure Eye of Wisdom Free from the Two Hindrances Illuminating the World.
However, the Buddha's virtues are boundless, each according to a single meaning.
The second layer and above may have eight aspects, adding the distance of going away from this.
Or there may be nine aspects, adding the word pure.
Based on this, if there is no such word, it is common to both the defiled and pure.
The number of realms above this gradually increases, and the events in between can be understood by analogy.
Among the five, the universal direction means that from a general perspective it is a direction, but within one side there are also many corners and angles.
The corner is the angle, and the literary style may be like this.
The thirteenth main realm is this SahÄ world.
Regarding the statement that its shape is like empty space, Jingfa says:
Both the MahÄyÄna and HÄ«nayÄna sÅ«tras say that the substance of empty space has no form or substance and cannot be seen. Now, it is said to have a shape. This is a mistake in the translation.

The Sanskrit text says samanta (universal), prabhÄsa (light), nagara (city), gagana (empty space), and Älaká¹£aá¹‡a (adorned). The translation should place shape before universal and empty space above city, and then combine and embellish it, saying that its shape is universal, and it is covered above with the adornments of the heavenly palace in empty space.
Jingfa's interpretation is indeed very reasonable, but now I will explain it according to the sutra, which is also reasonable.

It means that although space is formless, it is spoken of in terms of convention. In secular texts, space is called heaven, and heaven is said to be a circular vault, shaped like a drum, so it is said that the power of heaven surrounds the flat fields.
It is also like the Lotus Sutra saying that Brahma is the father of sentient beings, which is also spoken in terms of convention.
The fifteenth says its shape is like the character wan (å). Jingfa says:
The character srim is originally not a character, but a symbol of virtue, which is correctly called auspicious ocean clouds.
Its many virtues are as deep and vast as the ocean, and it benefits beings like clouds.
In the past, the Tripiá¹­aka master mistakenly translated laká¹£ma as aká¹£ara, and thus took the symbol to be a character, which is a mistake.

Now I interpret this symbol as the accumulation of myriad virtues, and thus call it wan (myriad). The intention is to use few words while encompassing the meaning, and should be combined to say myriad symbols.
The rest are easy to understand.
The third is a general conclusion of the remaining.
Here, it is not only the number of knots, but also a general indication of the abodes and so forth mentioned above.
The text is divided into four parts:

First, a general conclusion of the total number; second, below each according to its basis, a conclusion of the forms; third, below each of these, a conclusion of the retinue; fourth, below what has been said, an indication of its location.
Now, the first is raising the main buddha-realm species to conclude the number.
The buddha-realms concluded here are definitely the main buddha-realms, because the text below points out that there are two more layers surrounding the buddha-realms that cannot be spoken of.
The straight upward middle only has nineteen buddha-realms, but concludes with inconceivable, because it is a side discussion.
Otherwise,

how could there be only one main buddha-realm at the very bottom of a buddha-realm species? Therefore, it should be known that the main buddha-realms discussed above are discussed together horizontally and vertically, and thus are inconceivable.
Below, it concludes their location, saying they are in the fragrant rivers. Contemplate this.
In the second, concluding the shapes and types, first, three are listed as ten gates.
Since it says they surround it on all sides, we know they are on the sides.
Second, below what is called, it extensively explains the ten gates. The shapes have eighteen things.
Compared to the shapes of the various realms in the previous realm-wombs, it lacks the shapes of Mount Sumeru and ornaments. The rest are all the same, but this is different in terms of the realms.
Third, below such as these, it concludes by returning to the total number.
In the third, concluding the retinue, there are two layers of host and companion.
This each and every one refers to the number of dust motes that cannot be spoken of above.
If compared to the previous text, the main realms only increase in the number of layers above. Now, speaking in general terms, it says each and every one has realms equal to the number of dust motes.
It is also in order to manifest the meaning of inexhaustibility.
Each of them also has the number of dust motes as explained above. The words as explained above contain two meanings:
The first is to point out in general the number of those who can surround and those who are surrounded, and to surround one world. Not wanting to be verbose, it says as explained above.
The second is that as above also uses ten buddha-lands as the able to surround.
According to this, it seems that the translator's text is verbose and the principle is hidden. Why not say that each has the number of dust motes in ten buddha-lands?
If according to the previous meaning, then it is the translator's subtlety.
Fourth, it clarifies the location, which is the most central fragrant sea.
Since the sea is said to be in the fragrant river, it is clear that it goes sideways.
Below this, it enters the ninth sÅ«tra, the second part that clarifies the right-turning ten seas. There are ten of them, which surround the sea in the middle, each with its own kind of buddha-land.
The ten seas are divided into ten sections.
Now, the first is the sea of the treasury of defiled flames. The text has two parts:
First, it cites the great sea to determine the direction, which is the place to be surrounded, starting from the east.
Second, from next it clarifies the surrounding ocean. Within this there are two parts:
First, it clarifies the ocean flower buddha-womb;
Later, from at the very bottom of this it clarifies the buddha-womb that supports the buddha-womb, with twenty layers. The nine oceans below are similar.
Now, within the twenty layers of the first ocean, each has seven aspects:
First, the distance between them, second, the name of the buddha-womb, third, the shape, fourth, the support, fifth, the covering above, sixth, the retinue, and seventh, the name of the buddha.
Some explain the essence, some explain the purity, which is either eight or nine.
The first layer has no distance, but only the words at the very bottom. However, the text can all be understood. If there are difficulties, they will be explained.
In the fourteenth layer, it says the shape is like the four continents. In the water, what is habitable is called a continent.

According to the Abhidharma-koÅ›a, the eastern continent is like a half-moon, the southern continent is like a chariot, the western continent is like a full moon, and the northern continent is square.
The four continents have different shapes, but saying like means they are completely similar to this world.
This text does not have a heading or conclusion for the large number, but it can be known by analogy.
Second, from Buddha's disciples, to the south of this Flame Treasury of Impurity is the second boundless light wheel ocean.
The text for the nine oceans below all has two parts:

First, it cites the previous ocean as the basis, and then below there is a fragrant ocean, it clarifies the ocean that is based on it. They all do not cite the surrounding ocean as what is circled, so it says to the south.
The third ocean and below only say turning to the right and do not say to the south. The ten oceans surround the great ocean like a ring, so it is not exactly south.
It is like ten layers surrounding a single plate, which can be seen.
Also, from the second ocean onward, some do not have lotus flowers. The general explanation of the species says:
Some are based on lotus flowers, some are based on the ocean, so some do not have them.
The latter, the ocean that is the support, also has two parts:
First, it clarifies the ocean of the Flower Treasury Realm; later, at the very bottom of this and below clarifies the realm that is supported.
Among the twenty layers, the first world has seven parts in the text;
The last one has eight parts, adding pure;
The middle ones only have three, namely the distance, the number, the name of the realm, and the name of the Buddha. The remaining eight oceans are similar.
The two oceans have already been distinguished.

The third is the ocean of vajra jewel flame light, the fourth is the ocean of lapis lazuli jewel adornments, the fifth is the ocean of vajra wheel adornment base, the sixth is the ocean of Indra's net of lotus flowers, the seventh is the ocean of accumulated jewel fragrant treasuries, the eighth is the ocean of jewel adornments, the ninth is the ocean of vajra jewel heaps, and the tenth is the ocean of heavenly city jewel ramparts. The texts are all understandable.
If one wishes to explain the name of the Buddha in the realm, it is sufficient to ponder it. From here on enters the tenth chapter.
The third major section, starting from the tenth sutra, clarifies the oceans governed by the ten oceans.

Each ocean governs as many as the dust particles in an ineffable number of buddha lands. The present text only mentions ten for each, which makes one hundred oceans. There are also buddha-fields and the lands they support.
The ten oceans are divided into ten sections, but they only record the names of the ten oceans from before. This text is obviously easy to understand.
Each of the ten sections has two parts: first, it identifies the ocean that can govern in order to determine the direction, and then it lists the order of the oceans governed by next.
Within the governed, each has three parts:
First, starting from the edge of the ocean that can govern, it lists nine in sequence. Only the first section lacks one among the nine;
Second, below such and so forth, it concludes the large number of oceans governed by one ocean;
Third, below the closest, it extensively explains the closest ocean to the outer rim.
The text in each section has two parts:
First, it cites the name and essence of the buddha-field.
The second part, below the lowest of these, the worlds that are supported, are also all twenty layers.
Within this, there are four sections that skip over the intermediate ones:
First, it mentions the lower layer.
Second, it skips to the tenth and so on.
The vajra banner is the tenth world in the center of the incense ocean and world system.
Third, it skips again to the thirteenth, because it is equal to this central Saha world.
Fourth, it goes again to the twentieth layer, because it is the highest.
As for the highest, it is the highest in the world system.
If it is said to be the highest of the twenty layers, how does it get the name of the highest?
If it does not want to be verbose, why not add up to the highest?
However, the skipping over the intermediate ones is intended to be brief.
As for saying equal, it is because it is afraid of losing the sequence, and also because the upper, lower, horizontal, and vertical are all corresponding.

Moreover, each of these seas, as far as they extend, are beyond description. They are all arranged in a single direction facing the main sea that governs them. Therefore, the text below only says outside this sea and does not mention turning to the right and so forth.

The fifth fragrant sea adorned with vajra wheels governs only nine seas, and the text concludes with the sea closest to the outer rim of the world. The Sanskrit texts all lack the nine lines of text for this sea, but based on the examples before and after, this sea must definitely have a tenth sea that it governs.

Within the twenty layers of lands held by the sea closest to the outer rim of the world, the first text says, At the very bottom of this is a fragrant sea named Indra Flower Treasury. From the character xiang to the character zang is too long, because the fragrant sea has already been mentioned. Among the previous seas, there is no such example.
Even if the sea is without fault, it is inconvenient in the text.
The first ocean has nine oceans under its jurisdiction, missing one. Now this elder often omits the Sanskrit text, and later people annotate it, mistakenly writing similar palm leaves.
The rest can be understood.
The sequence of the ten oceans, but observing the previous commentary text, does not require repeating.
The third is the general summary and explanation, which is divided into five parts:
The first is the general summary of the total number, namely, each ocean governs one ineffable, and the ten oceans have ten ineffables. One ocean is one kind, so the number is the same.
The second, all rely on and below, concludes the basis of the ocean species.
It is the previously mentioned great lotus that holds the ocean of lands, named Banner of Various Light Filament Fragrance.
Now this is said to manifest the form of bodhisattvas, etc., which is the different names of this one flower according to meaning, because it has this function.

The name of the ocean floor in the middle is the same as before, because the ocean floor in the middle is the essence of this great flower, and it receives the general name, so it takes the name of the essence of the great flower. This may be a mistake by the translator.
Third, below each and every, it concludes the different aspects of the seeds.
This is mostly the same as the explanation of the chapter on seed-continua and the ten characteristics in the accomplishment of the world.
Fourth, below each and every, it concludes the lands within the seeds.
It says to form a world-net because each and every world is like a hole in a net, connecting with each other.
It is like holding with a net, horizontally and vertically intertwined, all corresponding, like a net of heavenly jewels.

Fifth, below in the Flower Treasury, it concludes by returning to the Flower Treasury, which is the place of establishment.ğŸ”½The above is the double explanation of the two chapters in the main text.
Second, the summary verses, a total of 111 verses, are divided into two:

The first one clarifies the essence of the Flower Treasury. The first sentence is the name, the next sentence is the indestructible magnitude which is the same as true nature, the next sentence is the adornment of virtues, and the last sentence is unobstructed abiding.
The remaining one hundred verses praise the net of lands that are upheld. Within this, there are two parts:
The first nine verses praise the seed of lands that can uphold, and the rest praise the various lands that are upheld.

Within the first part, the first verse praises the non-confusion of interpenetration, the next verse praises the arrangement in rows, the next verse praises the adornment of the essence of the seed of lands, the next two verses distinguish the shapes, the next verse praises the basis of support, the next two verses praise the direction and entry, and the last verse praises the empowerment of the Buddha's power.

The second part praises the lands upheld by the seed of lands. There are ninety-one verses, mostly summarizing the concluding text, but there are one or two differences, namely the essence and shape, the rest are all the same.
It is divided into ten main sections:
The first has twenty-eight verses, clarifying the differences in lands due to causes and conditions, which is the conclusion that each and every sentient being is completely filled.
Below it says because of the various abodes of sentient beings and each is empowered by the Buddha's power. This will be seen in the text.
The second has two verses showing the subtlety of the lands, which is the conclusion that each universally enters.
The third has ten verses on the nature of the worlds, and the conclusion is not present, but the meaning is seen in the previous sÅ«tra.
The fourth has five verses on the various adornments of the worlds, and the fifth has five verses on the uninterrupted adornments of each world's edge. These two are like the conclusion's name.
The sixth has ten verses on the shapes of the worlds, and the meaning is seen in the above text.
The seventh has two verses on the differences in kalpas of each world, and the eighth has eight verses on the appearance of Buddhas in each world. These two are also like the conclusion's name.
The ninth has ten verses on the presence or absence of light, which is each emitting jeweled light and each having a canopy of light clouds.
The tenth has eleven verses on the good and evil sounds, which is each expounding the ocean of Dharma.
The first part is divided into two:
The first half verse summarizes the chapter, saying it is difficult to conceive due to its various aspects.
The remaining verses extensively explain the characteristics of difficulty in conception, which is divided into two parts:
Nine and a half verses using analogies to illustrate, followed by eighteen verses of doctrinal explanation.
The former is divided into three parts:
The first three and a half verses clarify that due to defiled causes, there is formation and destruction of worlds.
The first verse and a half clarifies that the seeds are long-lasting, and there is formation and destruction of worlds;
The next verse clarifies that although the world-seed is one, there are differences in the worlds it contains;
The final verse concludes that it is due to the seeds of karma.
Next, there are three verses clarifying that due to pure causes:
One is the cause of pure mind, two are the causes and conditions of the Buddha's vow and spiritual powers, and the last one clarifies the cause of pure karma.
The last three verses comprehensively conclude the causes of defilement and purity: One is the cause of the mind's defilement and purity;
Two are the causes of the karma of discrimination, which is using the direct to illustrate the dependent, and also using the cause to illustrate the conditions.
The mind is the cause, which attracts the result of karmic maturation. The coarseness or subtlety of the result is entirely due to the conditions of karma.
The first three verses explain both mind and karma, because practice is karma.
It is also a metaphor for sentient beings having the same location but different views.
The last eighteen verses are the explanation of the Dharma, which is divided into three parts:
The first six explain defilement and purity, the next four explain formation and destruction, and the last eight explain suffering and joy.
Now, the first part is divided into two:
The first two reveal the different aspects of purity, and the last four discuss it in terms of causes.
Among them, the first verse is only about defilement, because of afflictions;
The next two are about both defilement and purity, because karma includes good and evil, and it belongs to bodhisattvas and sentient beings;
The last verse is only about purity, because it belongs to the Buddha.

There are four verses in the second part that reveal formation and destruction. The first verse shows that coarse destruction preserves the subtle. Destruction is caused by evil karma, and preservation is due to two causes: one is about the Buddha, and the other is about the karma of the good.
Therefore, the Lotus Sutra says, My pure land is not destroyed, and it is always filled with celestials and humans.
However, although destruction does not occur simultaneously, formation must occur in the same place.
Although they are said to be in the same place, they are always mutually absent, so it is difficult to conceive.
The next verse states that karma exists and establishes a place.
The next verse shows that the characteristics of the world are different, but the nature is without birth or cessation.

The last verse concludes by returning to causes and conditions. Internally, due to the transformation of the mind, there are myriad differences between purity and impurity. Externally, relying on the Buddha's conditions, how can it not be pure?
The next eight verses clarify suffering and joy. There are three parts:
The first three are general, discussing suffering and joy in terms of lands;
The next three are about the three evil destinies within a single land;
The last two clarify the joy of humans and gods.
The second two verses below each hair show the subtlety of lands:
The first verse raises the result, and the latter verse distinguishes it by contrasting it with the cause.
The thirtieth verse clarifies the essence, which also includes other meanings, which can be understood according to the explanation.
The fourth has five verses clarifying the adornments.

The fifth has five verses clarifying the limits of the adornments. Because it includes the adornments of the three times, there is no interruption. It concludes by returning to the Buddha, so a single dust mote universally sees.
The sixth, from Some have many realms with ten verses, clarifies the differences in the shapes of the realms.
The seventh, two verses, clarifies the duration of the realms.
The eighth, with eight verses, clarifies the number of Buddhas appearing.
The text is all understandable.
The ninth, ten verses, on the presence or absence of light, the first is absent, the last nine are present.
The tenth, with eleven verses, on the good and evil sounds in the realms, the first two are only evil in the evil paths;
Next, the humans and gods have both good and evil;
The last six are the good of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, not evil, which directly shows the ocean of Dharma expounded by each.

Chapter on Vairocana, Chapter 6. Below this enters the eleventh sutra. The first reason is that the previous chapter clarified the fruition of this cause, and now it discusses the cause of the previous fruition, answering the previous question on the cause, so it comes next.
The cause is the cause of the fruition, so it is named after the fruition.
Moreover, not taking the person to grasp the Dharma, how can one know whose cause it is?
The first part of the previous chapter said that Vairocana's vast eons of cultivating causes are what is purified and adorned, and now it is just revealing that matter.
Second, explaining the name, it is briefly said to be the universal illumination of light, and in detail it is as explained above.
Third, the purport and direction, it clarifies the vast causes as the direction, and proves and establishes the previous fruition as the purport.
Fourth, explaining the text.
This chapter is divided into three parts:
First, generally clarifying the time of the main story;
Second, below there is a world, specifically revealing the place of the main story;
Third, below in the first eon of that world of supreme sound, specifically revealing the main story within the time.
Now, the first is the eons equal to the dust motes of two buddha lands.
Second, in the explanation of the place, there are also three parts:
The first generally clarifies the ocean of lands.
The second, below this ocean of worlds, specifically clarifies a single land, omitting the land species.
The name of the land is Supreme Sound because many buddhas appear in the world and speak the sound of the Dharma.
Next, it reveals its characteristics and later explains the name of the eon, which can be understood.
The third, from All Buddha-sons, that Shengyin below, specifically points to one direction.
It is like now, in the Saha world, separately speaking of one four-continent world.
Within it, there are also three parts:
The first generally clarifies the place of sympathetic resonance;
The second, from All Buddha-sons, east of this forest below, specifically clarifies the residents who are able to sympathize;
The third, from All Buddha-sons, in that great forest below, specifically reveals the adornments of the Way-place.
Now, at the beginning, there are three:
The first clarifies the fragrant ocean. It is not an ocean that holds seeds, but simply like the ocean of the present four continents.
Second, from that ocean below, the ocean produces a flower mountain.
Third, from on that mountain below, it clarifies the forest on the mountain peak. First it is introduced, and then its adornments are revealed.
Speaking of this forest, the Buddha appears within it.
Speaking of the residents of the city, it generally includes those to be transformed.
The second, specifically clarifying the residents who are able to sympathize, also has three parts:
First, it lists the main and accompanying cities, second, it explains the main city, and third, it explains the accompanying city.
Now, the first.
Although there is a heavenly city, because the Buddha has appeared, the human city is the main one.
Second, below pure, it extensively explains the main city.
Among them, it first reveals the adornment of the place.
A watchtower is a guard post on top of a city wall, and a rampart is a separate earthen platform surrounding the city.
Utpala and so forth are the four colors of blue, red, yellow, and white lotus flowers.
From this great city, it shows the superiority of the people.
Third, below to the south of the city, it briefly explains the accompanying city.
Among them, it first distinguishes the name and type of the city;
Later, below each of these, it reveals the surrounding adornments.
The different worlds are slightly different in their arrangement, and they cannot be taken as examples.
Third, it clarifies the enlightenment site. First, it distinguishes the adornment of the site;
Second, below in front of the enlightenment site, it clarifies the lotus flower and fragrant ocean appearing for the Buddha.
The third main part specifically reveals the past events in time.
The text is divided into two parts:
First, it generally mentions many Buddhas in the eon;
Later, The first and below specifically reveal each one, clearly showing the past events.
The sutra does not end, so there is no concluding summary.
Now, at the beginning, it will first mention the general before speaking of the specific.
It says the first eon, which is the eon of various adornments.
Since it says first, there are even greater eons after this, which is not contradictory to reason.
In the second, specifically revealing the past events, it spans the events of four Buddhas, which are divided into four parts:

The first encounters the Buddha of All Meritorious Mountains and Supreme Clouds, the second is the Buddha of the Good Eyes Adorned with PÄramitÄs, the third is the Buddha of the Supreme Meritorious Ocean, and the fourth is the Buddha of the Renowned Lotus Eyes and Banner, each with the words disciples of the Buddha.
In the first Buddha, the text is divided into six parts:

First, it generally indicates the Buddha's name; second, it first shows the ripening of the assembly through auspicious signs; third, it directly reveals the arising of the Buddha; fourth, it warns through the light from the Buddha's tuft; fifth, it shows the assembly gathering when the opportunity arises; sixth, it extensively expounds the Dharma gates.
Now, the first.
Mountain of all merits means that his blessings and virtues are lofty and cannot be looked up to.
It is also called Sumeru, meaning that his samÄdhi and prajÃ±Ä are lofty and wonderful, and cannot be shaken.
Excellent cloud means that his compassion covers and his wisdom moistens, extending infinitely.
Second, below all Buddha's disciples, it first shows the ripening of the assembly through auspicious signs, divided into two:
First, it shows the auspicious signs that ripen the assembly; second, below in that world, it shows that the assembly is ripe upon seeing the auspicious signs.
In the first, there are three:
First, it indicates the time of the appearance, which is a hundred years before;
Second, below this maá¹‡i, it directly shows the ten kinds of auspicious signs.
Among them, it speaks of the practices in past lives, showing that the seeds are about to ripen.
It speaks of the Buddha's name, causing one to remember it.
Expounding the great practices and vows, causing them to cultivate and give rise to them.
Expounding the turning of the Dharma wheel, causing them to listen and study, giving rise to the Dharma eye.
Later, manifesting such... is the conclusion of the auspicious signs.
The two conditions are ripe, which can be understood.
Third, at that time... is the actual manifestation of the Buddha's appearance.
In this, it is divided into two parts:
First, the attainment of the Way in one place; second, as in... is the conclusion of the extensive pervasion.
In the beginning, first general, later its body... specific.
The specific manifestation of superior virtues has ten aspects:
